section.title: Web Service Graphical Interface
section.para: The web service graphical user interface (GUI) is a great tool that allow us to construct complex web service configurations in a friendly and nice interface, with it is possible to:

listitem.para: Import and Export configurations (in YAML file format) for existing web services.
View, Revert and Export old configurations for existing web services in the Web Service History screen.
Track all communication logs for each web service in the Debugger screen.

section.title: Web Service Overview
section.para: The "Web Services" link in the main screen of Admin Interface (in the System Administration box) leads to the web services overview screen, where you are able to manage your web service configurations. You can add new web services or change the configuration for the existing ones from this screen.

Every web service configuration screen has in the upper part of the screen a navigation path in a "bread crumbs" style. This navigation path is useful to know exactly in which part of the web service configuration we are, and also we can jump back to any level of the configuration at any time (this action will not save any changes).

note.para: To create a new web service, press the button "Add web service", and provide the needed information.

section.title: Web Service Add
section.para: The only required field in this part is the web service "Name" that needs to be unique in the system and non empty. Other fields are also necessary for the configuration like the "Debug Threshold" and "Validity" but this fields are already filled with the default value from each list.

The default value for "Debug Threshold" is "debug", under this configuration all communication logs are registered in the database, each Debug Threshold value is more restrictive and discard communication logs set for lower values.

itemizedlist.title: Debug Threshold levels (from lower to upper)

section.para: It is also possible at this time to define the network transport protocol for "OTRS as Provider" and "OTRS as requester".
Click on "Save" button to register the new web service in the database or click "Cancel" to discard this operation. On both cases you will be returned to the web service overview screen.

If you already have a web service configuration file in YAML format you can click on the "Import web service" button on the left side of the screen. for more information on importing web services please check the next section "Web Service Change".

note.para: To change or add more details to a web service, click on the web service name in the web service overview screen.

section.title: Web Service Change
section.para: On this screen you have a complete set of functions to handle every part of a web service, on the left side in the action column you can found some buttons that allows you to perform all possible actions over a web service:

note.para: "Configuration history" and "Debugger" will lead you to different screens.

section.title: Web Service Clone
section.para: To clone a web service, you need to click on the "Clone web service" button, a dialog will be shown where you can use the default name or set a new name for the (cloned) web service.

note.para: Remember the name of the web service must be unique within the system.

section.para: Click on "Clone" button to create the web service clone or "Cancel" to close the dialog.

section.title: Web Service Export
section.para: The "Export web service" button give you the opportunity to dump the configuration of the current web service into a YAML file, download it and store it on your file system. This can be specially useful if you want to migrate the web service from one server to another, for example from a testing environment to a production system.

warning.para: All stored passwords in the web service configuration will be exported as plain text.

section.para: Right after clicking the "Export web service" button a save dialog from your browser will appear (just like when you click on a downloadable file on a web page).

note.para: Each browser on each operating system has it own save dialog screen and style, depending on the browser and its configuration it is possible that no dialog is shown and the file is saved on a default directory on your file system. please check your browser documentation to know more about how it handle the downloadable files.

section.title: Web Service Import
section.para: A valid web service configuration YAML file is required to use the import web service feature, click on the "Import web service" button, browse for the configuration file or set the complete path on the input box.
Click "Import" button to crate a new web service form a file or "Cancel" to close the dialog.

note.para: The web service name will be taken from the configuration file name (e.g. if the file name is MyWebservice.yml the resulting web service will be named MyWebservice). If a web service is registered in the system with the same name as the web service that you want to import, the system will lead you to the web service change screen to let you change the name of the imported web service.

section.title: Web Service Delete
section.para: Some times its necessary to delete completely a web service, if you are in one of this cases you can press on the "Delete web service" button and a new dialog will appear asking if you are sure to delete the web service.
Clink on "Delete" to confirm the removal of the web service or on "Cancel" to close the dialog.

warning.para: Delete a web service can't be undone, please be careful when delete a web service.

section.title: Web Service Configuration Change
section.para: Returning to the web service change screen, now we are going to review the right side of it, where we have the possibility to modify all the general data for a web service like, name, description, debug threshold, etc. Also there are two more sections below that allows us to modify specific parameters for both communication types "OTRS as Provider" and "OTRS as Requester".

The web service configuration needs to be saved on each level, this means that if a setting is changed, links to other deeper parts of the configuration will be disabled forcing to save the current configuration level. After saving the disabled links will be re-enabled again allowing you to continue with the configuration.

On the "OTRS as provider" section it is possible to set or configure the network transport protocol, only previously registered network transport backends are shown on the list. To configure the network transport click on the "Configure" button. It is also possible to add new operations in this box, to do this select one of the available operations from the "Add Operation" list, this will lead you to the operation configuration screen. After saving the new operation it will be listed on the table above.
"OTRS as requester" is very similar to the previous one, but instead of operations you are able to add invokers

Click the "Save" button to save and continue configuring the web service, or "Save and finish" to save and return to the web service overview screen, or "Cancel" to discard current configuration level changes and return to web service overview screen.

note.para: On the rest of the Generic Interface configuration screens like Network Transport, operation, Invoker and Mapping, the initial configuration (add) screen will only present two options at the end "Save" and "Cancel", when the configuration is re-visited then a new option "Save and Finish" will appear. The behavior of this features is defined below.
"Save" will store the current configuration level in the database and it will return to the same screen to review your changes or to configure deeper settings.
"Save and Finish" will store the current configuration level in the database and it will return to the previous screen in the configuration hierarchy (to the immediate upper configuration level).
"Cancel" will discard any configuration change to the current configuration level and will return to the previous screen in the configuration hierarchy.

section.title: Web Service Provider Network Transport
section.para: In future the available network transport list will be increased, currently only "HTTP::SOAP" transport is available. each transport has different configuration options to setup and they might use different frontend modules to configure it, but they should look similar to the "HTTP::SOAP" transport configuration module.

For "HTTP::SOAP" protocol as provider the configuration is quite simple, there are only two settings "Namespace" and "Maximum message length" this fields are required. The first one is a URI to give SOAP methods a context, reducing ambiguities, and the second one it's a field where you can specify the maximum size (in bytes) for SOAP messages that OTRS will process.

section.title: Web Service Operation
section.para: The actions that can be performed when you are using OTRS as a provider are called "Operations", each operation belongs to a controller (controllers are collections of operations or invokers), normally operations from the same controller need similar settings and shares the same configuration dialog. But each operation can have independent configuration dialogs (if need it).

Name, Description, Backend, and Mappings are fields that normally appear on every operation, other special fields can appear on non default configuration dialogs like Remote System GUID field in SolMan Controller operations.

Normally there are two mapping configuration sections on each operation, one for the incoming data and another one for the outgoing data, you can choose different mapping types (backends) for each mapping way, since they configuration is independent from each other and also independent from the operation backend. The normal and most common practice is that the operation uses same mapping type in both cases (with inverted configuration). The complete mapping configuration is done in a separated screen, that depends on the mapping type.
The operation backend is pre-filled and is not editable, you set this parameter when you choose the operation on the web service edit screen, it is only informative.

In the left part of the screen on the action column you have the options: "Go back to web service" (discarding all changes since the last save) and "Delete", if you click on the last one, a dialog will emerge and ask you if you like to remove the operation, click on "Delete" button to confirm the removal of the operation and it configuration or "Cancel" to close the delete dialog.

section.title: Web Service Provider Transport
section.para: The network transport configuration for the requester is similar to the configuration for the provider. For the Requester "HTTP::SOAP" network transport there are also more fields to be set.
Apart from the "Endpoint" (URI of the Remote System web service interface to accept requestes) and "Namespace" that are required fields, you can also specify:

listitem.para: Encoding (like utf-8, latin1, iso-8859-1, cp1250, etc) for the SOAP message.

SOAPAction Header: you can to send an empty or filled SOAPAction header, Set to "No" and the SOAPAction header on the SOAP message will be an empty string, or set to "Yes" to send the soap action in Namespace#Action format and define the separator ("/" for .net web services and "#" for the rest).
Authentication: to set the authentication mechanism, set to "-" to not use any authentication or select one from the list and the details fields will appear.

note.para: Currently only "BasicAuth" (HTTP) authentication mechanism is implemented you can decide to use it or not depending on the Remote System configuration. If used, you must provide the User Name and the Password to access the remote system.

warning.para: If you supply a password for authentication and after you export the web service to a YAML file this password will be revealed and will be write into a plain text string inside the YAML file, be aware of it and take the needed precautions.

section.title: Web Service Invoker
section.para: The actions that can be performed when you are using OTRS as a requester are called "Invokers", each invoker belongs to a controller (controllers are collections of operations or invokers), normally invokers from the same controller need similar settings and shares the same configuration dialog. But each invoker can have independent configuration dialogs (if need it).

Name, Description, Backend, and Mappings are fields that normally appear on every invoker, as well as the list of event triggers other special fields can appear on non default configuration dialogs like Remote System GUID field in SolMan Controller invokers.

Normally there are two mapping configuration sections on each invoker, one for the incoming data and another one for the outgoing data, you can choose different mapping types (backends) for each mapping way, since they configuration is independent from each other and also independent from the invoker backend. The normal and most common practice is that the invoker uses same mapping type in both cases (with inverted configuration). The complete mapping configuration is done in a separated screen, that depends on the mapping type.
The invoker backend is pre-filled and is not editable, you set this parameter when you choose the invoker on the web service edit screen, it is only informative.

Event triggers are events within OTRS like "TicketCreate", "ArticleSend", etc. That act as triggers to execute the invoker. Each invoker needs to have at least one event trigger registered, or the invoker will be useless (because it will never be called). The asynchronous property of the event triggers define if the OTRS process will handle the invoker or if it will be delegated to the Scheduler.

note.para: OTRS Scheduler is a separated process that execute tasks in the background, in this way the OTRS process will not be affected if the Remote System takes a long time to respond, if is not available or if there are network problems, otherwise it will looks like OTRS is slow or non responsive. This is why is highly recommend to use asynchronous event triggers always

section.para: To add an Event trigger first select the event family from the first list, then the event name from the second list, then set the asynchronous property (if unchecked means that the event trigger will not be asynchronous) and then click on the plus button. a new event trigger will be created and it will be listed on the invoker "Event Triggers" list.

To delete an Event trigger, simply locate the event trigger to be deleted in the "Event Triggers" list and click on the trash icon at the end of the row. It will open a dialog that ask you if you are sure to delete the event trigger. Click "Delete" to remove the event trigger from the list, or "Cancel" to close the dialog.

In the left part of the screen on the action column you have the options: "Go back to web service" (discarding all changes since the last save) and "Delete", if you click on the last one, a dialog will emerge and ask you if you like to remove the invoker, click on "Delete" button to confirm the removal of the invoker and it configuration or "Cancel" to close the delete dialog.

section.title: Web Service Mapping
section.para: There are cases on some web services when you need to map or change data structure, because normally a web service is used to interact with an external system, in these cases some values needs to change in order to match with the remote expected data.
Exists the option to create different types of mapping, but here we are going to talk about the only one available currently on the system, this is the Mapping::Simple module.
This module give you the oportunity to set default values to map for each key or value on a whole communication data.

At the beggenning of the screen you could see a general section where you have the chance to set default rules that will apply for all the unmapped keys and values. Basicly exist three options for each one, these are listed below.

listitem.para: Keep (leave unchanged): doesn't touch the keys or values on any way.
Ignore (drop key/value pair): in short words, it deletes the key/value pair, because delete the key and consecuently it's value, when ot apply for values, just the value is deleted keeping the key.

MapTo (use provided value as default): all keys or values without a map rule, will take it as default to set it's new value, when you select this option a new text field for the map value will showed next to the select box.

section.para:
Clicking on the "+" button for new key map, a new dialog for a single mapping configuration will be displayed. There you can define a map for a single key, with the next options:
Exact value(s): the old key string will exchange with the new one in an exact way.
Regular expression: The key string will be replaced following a regular expression rule.
Pressing the new value map "+" button a new row for a value map will be displayed. Here also it's possible to define rules for each possible value with the same values as for the key. You can add many maps for values as you want, and if you want to delete one of them, just push on the "-" button for each row. Delete the complete section for a key it's possible clicking on the "-" button located on the up right corner of the dialog box.
As in the rest of screens for the web services you have to option to save or save and finish, with the last option you will be redirected to the previous screen.

Now, if you want to delete a whole mapping configuration, the only way to do it, it's go back to the corresponding operation or invoker screen, look for the mapping for incomming or outgoing field and set on it an empty value, save the configuration to apply changes.
In a future more mapping types will be included.

section.title: Web Service History
section.para: Every change on the web service configuration creates a new entry on the web service history (as a journal). The web service history screen displays a list of all configuration versions for a web service, each row (version) on the "Configuration History List" means one of that entries in the web service history.

Click on one of that rows to show the whole configuration as it was on that particular date / time, the configuration will be shown in the "History details" section of this screen, from there you are also able to export the selected web service configuration version or restore that version into the current web service configuration.
"Export web service configuration" behaves exactly as the "Export web service" feature on the web service change screen, for more information refer to that section.

If changes on the current web service configuration does not work as expected and is not easy to manual revert the changes, you can click on the "Revert web service configuration" button. This will open a dialog to ask you if you are sure to revert the web service configuration. Click "Revert web service configuration" in this dialog to replace the current configuration with the selected version, or click "Cancel" to close the dialog.

warning.para: Remember that all stored passwords in the web service configuration will exported as plain text.
Please be careful when you restore a configuration because this change can't be undone.

section.title: Web Service Debugger
section.para: The Debugger stores the log for a web service, in the debugger screen you can track all the web service communications for either provider or requester kind.

When this screen is shown the request list starts to load, after the list is fully filled you can choose one of the rows (that means a communication sequence) to check its details. This details will appear on a box below.
You can narrow the communication list using the filter on the right part of the screen, you can filter by:

listitem.para: Date: before and / or after a particular date

section.para: After filter settings are set push the "Refresh" button, a new list will be displayed meeting your search criteria.

note.para: Depending on the search criteria for the filters the new list could return no results.

section.para: On the left part of the screen under the action column you have the chance to "Go back to the web service" or clear the debugger log by pushing the "Clear" button. This will open a dialog that ask you to confirm erase of the log. Click "Clear" in the dialog button to perform the action or click on "Cancel" to close this dialog.
In the "Request details" section you can see all the details for the selected communication. Here you can track the complete flow and check for possible errors or confirm success responses.
